posts.text:
Some of my favourite classics, and why you might like to read them too!


a. The Count of Monte Cristo - by Alexander Dumas

  • A historical fiction, set during the era of Napoleon - 1815-1839, written in 1844
  • Masterpiece revenge arc
  • Amazing prose
  • It's long, and that might put many off, but honestly I wish there were another thousand pages just so I could keep reading more.


b. Catch-22 - Joseph Heller

  • Satirical historical fiction, written in achronological order, set during WW2
  • "...the only war novel I've ever read that makes any sense" - Harper Lee, and I could not agree more
  • I think this book is incredible for the way it manages to juggle complete satire, yet utter seriousness. The gags and jokes all reflect the bitter underlying nature of their reality - these soldiers are going to die, and there's nothing they can do about it
  • To paraphrase Yossarian from the book, "I know someone has to die, I'm just saying I don't think there's any reason it needs to be me"
  • I recently re-read this book, and I loved every moment. It's just beautiful. I knew what was going to happen and it still made me feel like I'd been caught up in the war - certainly encouraged some transient nihilism, at least.


c. Perfume: The Story of a Murderer - by Patrick Sskind

  • It's been 9 years since I read this book, and I still vividly remember particular scenes
  • The premise is: a shunned and ugly man, born with a godlike power to parse scents and recreate them, becomes a murderer
  • Really interesting and unique plot
  • Disturbing, yet morbidly interesting


d. The Picture of Dorian Gray - by Oscar Wilde

  • Short, exciting, suspenseful - again, it's been a long time since I read it, but I recall loving the way the author made you feel frustration, anger and sadness
  • I also recall a particular quote from early on, that has continued to resonate with me for the majority of a decade: "Don't do anything in the evening, that you would be ashamed to discuss the next morning over breakfast" or something to that effect...
  • The concept is, again, just incredibly original and I highly recommend it to anyone with an interest in classics


e. Of Mice and Men

  • A very very short novella, and yet so poignant
  • I can't say much more than that really. It's innocent. It's lovely. And it can make you cry in just a hundred pages. If that appeals to your emotional masochism, then this book is for you.




These are just five of my top picks that came to mind tonight, but I will certainly be adding more and, hopefully, this will remind myself why I love these books so much and make me spend a little more time re-reading them!
posts.title: My Book Recommendations #2 - Classics

posts.text:
This is the start of a series where I'll try to list a few book recommendations every few days in different genres, to hopefully bring at least one other person the same amount of pleasure and satisfaction that I've gained from them. This is particularly important to me now since I've found myself so caught up in cryptocurrencies that I'm not otherwise making time for the reading I was so keen to pick up this year.


Fantasy Genre

a. Kingkiller Chronicles by Patrick Rothfuss

  • Beautiful prose, first character, and only one POV
  • The number of subtle clues and hints that he has in his books has allowed fans to discuss

their theories for years despite the ridiculously long wait for the final book

  • Really cool magic system
  • Classic, satisfying epic fantasy escapism


b. The Stormlight Archives by Brandon Sanderson

  • Incredible world building
  • Realistic, flawed characters who struggle with mental illness and each have many facets
  • Incredibly mature, but also familiar to any epic fantasy reader
  • He is prolific and publishes often, consistently, with incredible talent for twists
  • His magic system here is just absurd
  • This is his "magnum opus" series, still in the works, but is part of the "Cosmere" universe, to which many of his other books belong


c. American Gods by Neil Gaiman

  • Standalone book - might appeal to many who are time poor/require closure
  • Hard to describe what makes this book so appealing...
  • The character is quiet, and cautious, and it's quite true to third person in that it often feels like you don't entirely know what he thinks
  • The prose is beautiful
  • He brings to life the ancient pantheons of gods in a modern day United States in a unique manner


d. The Gentlemen Bastard Series by Scott Lynch

  • A fantasy series with a focus on one city of rats and robbers, rather than a universe of gods
  • It has stellar platonic bonds, which are a pleasure to read and experience vicariously
  • AWESOME HEIST and CON ARTISTRY! Very satisfying, full of suspense, with some twists on top


e. The First Fifteen Lives of Harry August by Claire North

  • What happens if every time you die? You're reborn, you remember, but it is the exact same life as before. You live forever in the loop of your life. Like groundhog day of a lifetime.
  • If you can kill someone, but then be reborn and they'll still be alive, is it equally immoral?
  • If you know someone will do wrong, can you pass judgement before they ever do?
  • If someone harms you, how easily can you forgive them in the next life?



  • This is the most unique fantasy book, the least well known I'm sure, and while it was a pleasure to read, it was also incredibly thought provoking. The above questions are some of the questions it made me ask myself, and when it becomes possible, I can't wait to hear other people's opinions in a comments section
  • Also, it's not just philosophical. There's drama. There's suspense. The world is going to end, and it is up to Harry to save it or doom it. But it was really the questions it poses that make me recommend the book.


Those are just 5 of the fantasy books that came to my mind first! Will likely repost others as I recall them
posts.title: My Book Recommendations #1 - Fantasy

posts.text:
For this first post, I want to introduce all of you to one of, if not the, most infamous example of unethical experimentation: The US Tuskegee Syphilis Study. A study so abhorrent that it became the raison d'tre for the Belmont Report, a document which outlines the 3 fundamental ethical principles which must be respected in modern day research.

  1. 1. Respect for persons:
  • - Humans should be treated as autonomous subjects with free will and should be informed about risks/benefits without coercion

  1. - Individuals with compromised capacity to consent should be given more protection

  2. - Requiring "Informed Consent"


  4. 2. Beneficence

  • - Maximise benefits and minimise risks - to both the participants and society

  • - Benefits should be expected to be greater than the risks


  2. 3. Justice
  • - Is it fair? If there are potential benefits, the study should not exclude participants from the study on the basis of race, or poverty, nor should a study be conducted which only includes minority groups with risks involved, unless the research is intended to target this group in particular as part of its design.


But first, some fun facts to lay a foundation (or maybe spice future dinner conversation with):

  1. 1. Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum


2. Before it became treatable, it was seen as a shameful disease, and it often lay unnoticed for years before manifesting itself as a rash, disfiguring nodules, cardiac failure, dementia and more.


3. Just as it can present and manifest in a plethora of different ways; over history it has been given a plethora of names, usually inspired by that country's political opinions e,g. To the English, Germans and Italians? "The French Disease", To the Dutch? "The Spanish Disease". To the Turks? "The Christian Disease"... and so on...


4. The true origin of syphilis is still disputed, but one of the leading theories is that it began in the Americas until it was brought to Europe by the returning crew of Christopher Columbus.



With that out of the way, the following is a rough outline of what has become known simply as the Tuskegee Syphilis Study, and it should become apparent how, if the Belmont Report had existed earlier, it would have violated all 3 of their principles.

THE TUSKEGEE SYPHILIS STUDY

  • It was the 1930s and Syphilis was being treated with heavy metals or giving malaria, in the hopes that somehow these could somehow combat the condition. A study was to be conducted to test whether these were actually effective, but to do so they would need controls, samples of people who had never had treatment with whom the heavy metal/malarial group could be contrasted. How to achieve this? Well, luckily, an early 1900s survey had showed that many Black Americans working on farms in Tuskegee were poor, uneducated and often had syphilis without any treatment (an observation which, incidentally, no one made any real effort to act upon after the survey was published).


    • These longstanding, untreated patients were thus invited to participate in a study, wherein they could be examined to determine the effects of longstanding syphilis, versus populations who had had syphilis diagnosed and treated with the aforementioned "medicine". These patients were bribed into participating in the study through a combination of financial reward and the promise of "exclusive special medical treatment" for "their blood condition", though as we will see, this exclusive treatment was intentionally designed NOT to be effective against syphilis.

    • In 1936, unexpectedly, through my contemporary eyes at least, their published research suggested that perhaps heavy metals and induced malaria actually DID seem to work, because those who had received them were 2-3x less likely to have cardiovascular or neurological complications (what we call "Tertiary Syphilis") compared with our Tuskegee group.

      (N.B: It's important to note, however, that these two groups probably had many other undervalued differences between them e.g. if one group was so disparately treated (ignored post-survey and often not even told that they had syphilis), they likely had all the confounding problems of poverty/low education alongside their syphilis and perhaps it was the presence of these confounding problems that made tertiary syphilis more common, rather than the active treatment of mercury and malaria.)

    • So where were we? Ah, yes. We now had evidence that perhaps heavy metals and malaria HELPED those with syphilis. So, did we end our research and begin offering to treat these poor individuals? Of course not. That would be expensive, and perhaps even more importantly, we would then LOSE this very rare group of untreated syphilis patients, from whom we could learn so much more as their disease continues to slowly kill them.

  • It was for these reasons that the study was not terminated, the patients were not told of the results, and they were never given any effective dose of the treatments they'd helped to justify. Given the nasty side effects of heavy metals and malaria, perhaps this doesn't sound so awful, but when you learn that soon after, in the 1940s, penicillin became both widely available and KNOWN to ELIMINATE Treponema pallidum and yet NO ONE offered to treat this tiny disadvantaged group of known syphilis patients.

    (N.B Tiny caveat, tertiary syphilis can be treated with penicillin, but in some fairness, at this time they weren't 100% sure that such late stage disease could be treated... the point though is that they obviously never even tried, even though that WOULD be valuable research, because they realised that they had in their grasp one of the last groups of untreated syphilis in the world, since penicillin would soon be offered to anyone as soon as they were diagnosed from this point forward).

So as time goes on, WW2 begins, and drafting occurs across the US and our Tuskegee syphilis group faces yet another obstacle: if their patients are drafted, they'll get a routine medical examination, and they'll be diagnosed with syphilis and be mandated for antibiotic treatment. Likely worried about losing their precious group to the war and medical aid, there is evidence they actually petitioned the head of the local draft board and said something like "this study is one of the last opportunities for scientific research like this", which seemed to be sufficient, since almost none of the participants were ever drafted.

Eventually, Peter Buxton, a social worker who'd been tracking down those with STI while working for US Public Health (the same department, by the way, who'd been behind this whole study from the start) learnt about the Tuskegee Syphilis group. He tried to lead protests, raise awareness, and unfortunately did not achieve very much, until one late night dinner with friends, while he recounted the inefficacy of his protests, one of them - a journalist - offered to take his story to a more experienced colleague Jean Heller.

And then the news broke, at last, in 1972: "Syphilis victims in US study went untreated for 40 years". There were demonstrations the next day. In 1973 a 10 million dollar class action law suit was settled, giving free medical and burial to all still living participants (not so many, unfortunately), And this is what sparked Senator Kennedy to start a commission, eventually resulting in the publication of the Belmont Report.

So it ends on a happy note, no? Except that we have to remember a few honest truths.
1. The US Public Health service exists for A:LL of the public good, and this was gross discrimination against a poor, uneducated racial minority. We could argue some kind of utilitarian ethics, but once penicillin was known to be cheap and effective, there was no longer any NEED to learn about tertiary syphilis - because we could prevent it from almost ever developing in the US again.

2. These researchers weren't exactly undercover. They published their studies, presented at conferences, and clearly NO ONE else thought deeply about the immorality of the research, or if they did they kept quiet against better judgement. Does this mean all scientists are evil? Hopefully not, but it does suggest that ethics as we understand them are malleable, they fluctuate depending on person, time and place. This is easy to see when we consider slavery, or the lack of women's rights, but it's perhaps even more disturbing when we see it among medical professionals, who've undoubtedly at least heard of, if not sworn, the Hippocratic Oath. In particular, it's disturbing because the ethical foundations of modern research in the United States was only developed in the 70s, either we, or our parents, were part of.

This is a lot, and is probably far too large given the posts I've read so far, but it's an interesting study and one which too few people have ever really heard of in detail. I come from a medical background, and I am optimistic about the great benefits of research and the values which motivate many to conduct it, but if we simply shy away from the ugly truths of history, then we leave studies like this in popular ignorance, for the fodder of conspiracy theorists and the legacy tales of those descended from our unfortunate Tuskegeean victims.

If people enjoyed this, let me know and I'll write more articles like it about other unethical or shocking studies of the past!

LogicalLadder
posts.title: Unethical Science of History (and what we learnt from it) #1

posts.text:
These are 4 of the medical-themed books that Ive read and my opinions/summaries/thoughts regarding them. Hopefully I can tempt you into reading a few as well, but if not, I hope that you nevertheless enjoy the post.

1.The Brain That Changes Itself Norman Doige

Disclaimer: This is a book I read at 15, and had a major influence on my decision to enter the medical field for a career rather than engineering or another more mathematically-oriented science field. As a result, I feel obliged to discuss it, even though the lens of hindsight elucidates the validity of a number of criticisms, namely its exaggerative language and sometimes misleading implications.

This book captures the excitement of neuroplasticity, exploring the frontier of neurological medicine and the capacity for the brain to heal and learn following extreme insults. Its an incredible book, and though it can be faulted for portraying neuroplasticity as a very new discovery (when in fact its been accepted quite broadly in the community for decades now), and also for its focus on anecdotal evidence, the book doesnt try to sell snake oil or try to claim that every solution already exists in a bottle of homoeopathically diluted water.

The following are two of the anecdotal stories that have stuck with me for almost 10 years now, and as Ive written previously books which offer you nuggets your memory can cling to for a decade are usually worth the time.

A)Cheryl a woman suffering the unfortunate side-effect of ototoxicity from her medication (I believe it was gentamicin, a common and important antibiotic that must nevertheless be carefully titrated in dose for exactly this reason). This left her with damage to her vestibulocochlear nerve, specifically the vestibular (balance) component, resulting in a total lack of balance and, horrifyingly, the sensation of perpetual falling. (Balance is not one of the 5 commonly recognised senses, but it is certainly one of the most important, since it represents our ability to understand our acceleration through space in different directions and without it we can neither maintain our balance nor guide our eyes when trying to follow moving objects).

-Paul Bach-y-Rita, now deceased, treats this woman using an ingenious and bizarre technique. He gives Cheryl a helmet with an in-built accelerometer, to replace the vestibular system shes lost, and then has it transmit electrical impulses along a plate which rests on her tongue. These pulses move in directions representative of the movement of her own head and, as the story goes, her brain quickly recognises this and begins to use the information from her tongue to replace its sense of balance.

-So far, this sounds plausible to me, although for an invention so incredible my red flags start to flap as I notice the absence of significant external corroboration of their validity. The story becomes even more extraordinary, however, when you learn that over time, Cheryl notices that her sense of balance persists even after removing the helmet until, eventually, she no longer needs it at all.

-The theory given in the book to explain the above is that perhaps what has been happening is that the damage to her vestibular nerve had resulted in a lot of noise, meaning her brain could no longer figure out which signals were accurate and which were false. When it was given accurate information from elsewhere, it was able to adjust its synapses to accordingly modulate the vestibular signals relative to their validity in other words, it could focus on the neurons that were still functioning and suppress the activity of neurons which were impaired.

-Bizarrely, the researchers have tried to perform more controlled trials to validate their claims electrical signals on the tongue that represented direction vs electrical signals that actually had no meaning and I believe the outcome was little difference between the two groups: both improved. They then began to question whether there was something special about electrical stimulation to the sensory nerves of the tongue, and here it becomes a little wishy-washy, and, I believe, less plausible.

-Nevertheless, my childlike eagerness to believe in wonders such as this has persisted, and as they slowly improve their tech and adapt it to help patients following traumatic brain injury, or even to allow blind people to see, Im eager to see whether or not Cheryl was a coincidence, or whether there is merit after all.

(Certainly the application of allowing the blind to see seems to have been repeatedly proven, which is extraordinary and I encourage those interested to google it)

B)A woman born with only half a brain

-This is a story of a woman born with, effectively, only one hemisphere of functioning brain, due to a large stroke in-utero.

-Whats incredible here is that this woman is able to function at all. Many probably know that the human brain is lateralised and functionally asymmetrical ie. Our left and right hemispheres perform slightly different tasks. The motor cortex on the left side, for instance, is responsible for the movement of the right side of the body, as well as the motor speech area of most people (Brocas area).

-One might expect, then, that this girl would be born with only the use of half of her body, but her brain has remodelled and so although one side was significantly less coordinated, she was far from entirely paralysed. This kind of incredible neuroplasticity is to my knowledge unheard of if the insult is acquired later in life, but with the gift of foetal youth, her brain had the chance to fundamentally change its architecture and adapt.

-Even more impressively, according to Doiges recounting, despite deficits in certain abstract thinking, she had strengths elsewhere that surpassed even the average person for instance her autobiographical memory was incredible, capable of immediately telling her the day of the week it was on a certain date, not through the mathematical pattern (which he notes she had also worked out), but simply by recalling that date to her mind and knowing the day as if it were today.

Naturally, the book contains many more stories than this, with far more detail and hypothesizing involved, but I hope these two stories are incredible enough that you might also consider reading it, and if not, perhaps by reading these you learnt a little bit anyway.

For the sake of brevity, and because I realise I spent far too much time on the above, I will now try to summarise and recommend books using just a few short dot points.

2) The Boy Who Was Raised as a Dog - Bruce D. Perry

  • I listened to this on Audible last year, and I cannot rate it highly enough!
  • A series of true case stories collected by Bruce D. Perry, a renowned child-trauma psychiatrist and recounted here to teach lessons, and highlight the evolution of paediatric psychiatry over the course of his career.
  • Quite confronting at times, often discussing the stories of children abused by their family, but I can honestly say that this book enriched my empathy and compassion for those who've suffered these horrors, and will hopefully improve my own ability to help such patients in the future.
  • Very scientifically grounded, in a landscape where unfortunately psychiatry is largely considered the least evidence-based medical specialty, and although he discusses his own theories, I believe he makes not only valid rationale for them, but emphasises key messages that are not beholden to any particular therapy, 2 of which that I took away being:

1. During abuse, a child is powerless. In order to help them, any treatment moving forward needs to involve their autonomy as much as possible. Just as paternalistic medicine towards adults is being phased out, so too does the paternalistic nature of medicine towards children. They may have been abused, but they often have great insight into their own condition when given the chance to discuss it, and for them to heal, they need to finally feel like they're in control of their life and mental state again.


2. Identical-seeming trauma can have dramatically different responses across different individuals, and they accordingly each have their own idiosyncratic response to treatments. Therefore any psychiatric treatment of these children needs to be modified in accordance with not only large evidence, but with the art of understanding this patient's unique needs.

Honestly, just read this book. If you're a parent, PLEASE read it. If you're going to be a parent, PLEASE read it. And if you just have a parent, PLEASE read it. I think this should almost be compulsory reading before parenthood, since although terrifying, it highlights how even the most benevolent intentions can harm a child, and that for something so important, it's odd that no standardised education really exists for helping parents learn to parent.

3) House of God - Samuel Sham

  • The Catch-22 of the medical field, albeit written in a far less skilled way
  • It's a hilarious, satirical story inspired by the author's own experiences as an intern in the US
  • What's shocking is how accurately it depicts the field of medicine, however. Of course, I like to think the situation has largely improved since then, and certainly my country does not have quite the same level of pressure on new doctors as the American healthcare system seems to. Nevertheless, this book captures the depressingly accurate heart of modern medicine:

1. Medicine is like a revolving door, with buffing and turfing (read to understand what that means).This kind of message reminds me eerily of the philosophy in Catch-22 of perpetual delegation of tasks.

2. The practice of medicine can, at times at least, be a rather thankless and tedious task, full of beauracy and paperwork and as a result it is common, I suspect, for many to become jaded, cynical and lose the perspective that each patient is a unique person, greater than their constituent co-morbidities.

4) This is Going to Hurt Adam Kay

- The first audiobook I ever listened to, and the one which persuaded me that perhaps my snobbish view that audiobooks could never compete with actually reading the book was incorrect. Adam Kay is a UK doctor-turned-comedian and delivers an expert performance of his book, a series of journal entries from his time climbing the hospital ladder: intern -> junior doctor -> junior trainee in O&G -> senior trainee and so on.

- This book is a more realistic, modern and UK-based description of what its like to be a doctor. Far more humorous, and less depressing and cynical, than the house of God, this book nevertheless has an undercurrent of a rather serious problem, and its one that I admittedly found resonated with me deeply, though again I feel the situation is far better in the country I live in.

- It's short, its sweet, its hilarious, and I think its an absolute MUST for anyone either already into audiobooks or looking for one to prove that theyre worth the time. I dare say that his written version could not compare to the audio.


5) The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat - Oliver Sax

  • Super interesting collection of cases that Oliver Sax encountered, all demonstrating totally different neurological pathologies.
  • Very well written - you can see why it became a bestseller
  • I doubt I need to say much more. Give it a go.


6) The Emotional Life of Your Brain - Richard J. Davidson with Sharon Begley

  • Davidson tries to support his own psychological theory of emotion by recounting the studies his and other labs have performed.
  • The gist is that there are 6 major emotional traits, with distinct underlying brain structures and pathways
  • The idea then is that by performing certain tasks, one might even be able to strengthen these tasks, or at least begin to understand why they are the way that they are
  • He really heavily promotes mindfulness and meditation, and discusses the vipassana retreat he went on. Having gone on one myself, I can see why he's such a fan. It was an incredible experience, one I'll do again, and I am extremely grateful to this book for bringing it to my attention in a way that it may not have been ever again.


This is a long post, so although I could go on and on and on, I'll stop. I hope some of you out there, reading, consider picking one of these books up. I think that ultimately, while peer-reviewed literature and academic journals is where we can learn some of the most objective truths, as I believe Dr V. S Ramachandrun said to Doige, "If you met a llama and it spoke english, would you really try to ignore it by simply saying that every other llama hasn't spoken before, and therefore there isn't enough evidence that llamas can speak?" I'm sure I'm butchering the quote, but I think the message is, we can still learn a lot from individual cases, even if the treatments themselves cannot be immediately generalised to broader populations. Moreover, it's through stories that humans have always taught and learnt, and it is far easier to remember the story of Cheryl, and thus remember the consequences of improper gentamicin prescribing, than it is to simply memorise the list of side-effects from a textbook.


Anyway, as always, I hope you've enjoyed!

-LogicalLadder
posts.title: My Book Recommendations #3 - Medical-Themed Books

posts.text:
CIA MK-Ultra Studies (1953-1967/75)


This is a brief timeline overview of the MK-Ultra Studies performed by the CIA:


1953: CIA believed Soviet Russia was developing mind control weapons and so wanted to race them to the finish line and looked into whether psychedelics such as LSD could be useful

  • "We intend to investigate the development of a chemical material which causes a reversible, nontoxic aberrant mental state, the specific nature of which can be reasonably well predicted for each individual. This material could potentially aid in discrediting individuals, eliciting information, and implanting suggestions and other forms of mental control."

- Richard Helms, internal CIA memo


  • Precautions must be taken not only to protect operations from exposure to enemy forces but also to conceal these activities from the American public in general, wrote the CIAs Inspector General in 1957. The knowledge that the Agency is engaging in unethical and illicit activities would have serious repercussions in political and diplomatic circles and would be detrimental to the accomplishment of its mission.


Operation Midnight Climax

1954: establishment of a web of CIA-run safe-houses in San Francisco, Marin County, California, and New York City


1955: CIA decorated a bedroom on 225 Chestnut St, San Francisco

  • Hired Berkeley engineering student to install 2-way mirrors and bugging equipment
  • George White (FBI narcotics expert leading this) sat behind the mirror and waited
  • Prostitutes would lure unsuspecting men inside where they'd be dosed with LSD
  • Sex workers were then given money and a promise to be protected when they had (as was inevitable) run-ins with the law in the future
  • The agency also analyzed when in the course of a sexual encounter information could best be extracted from a source, eventually concluding that it was immediately after sex.
  • I toiled wholeheartedly in the vineyards because it was fun, fun, fun, White later said. Where else could a red-blooded American boy lie, kill, cheat, steal, rape, and pillage with the sanction and blessing of the All-Highest?"


1963: The CIAs experiments with LSD persisted until 1963 before coming to a fairly anticlimactic end. In the spring of 1963, John Vance, a member of the CIA Inspector Generals staff, learned about the projects surreptitious administration to unwitting non-voluntary human subjects. At this point, the project was gradually scaled back:


1965: San Fran house closed


1966: NY house closed


1975: The operation was first brought to public attention in 1975 by the Church Committee and the Rockefeller commission. Unfortunately, 2 years earlier in 1973 the director had ordered all files be destroyed hence testimonies + small number of surviving documents were all that remained for the investigation.


(As an aside, though not particularly relevant to the LSD-chain of MK-Ultra, declassified documents were released in December 2018 which included a letter to an unidentified doctor discussing work on six dogs made to run, turn and stop via remote control and brain implants, which I find pretty cool, albeit I'm somewhat sceptical.)


Lastly, I'll share a few interesting case examples of people affected by these experiments:

a. Unnamed man who was from the army enlisted to a study which was meant to be on the usefulness of masks in chemical warfare was actually subjected to psychedelics without his knowledge developed paranoia


b. Dr Frank Olsen, Army Scientist for CIA, who one day 'jumped out of a window'

  • Turned out much later that he worked for the CIA and that he'd gone on a camp trip with colleagues, drunk some smuggled alcohol which, as I understood it from the Great Courses Lecture Series, had actually been spiked with LSD He never fully recovered form it went and received psychotherapy eventually he then killed himself... or did he?
  • As it turns out, when his sons demanded a second autopsy many years later, there was evidence of a bleed on the left side of his head, consistent with being hit ?Murder to quiet him and hide the project? **Conspiracy**


c. Harold Blauer (1910 January 8, 1953) was an American tennis player who died as a result of injections of 450 mg 3,4-Methylenedioxyamphetamine

  • He sought psychiatric help at NY psychiatric institute in late 1952 depression following divorce
  • Used as test subject while there by Army Chemical Corps which had a classified agreement with the institute to permit them to test chemical warfare compounds
  • MDMA analogue given IV
  • In reports it was shown that he feared the rejections and asked them to stop, even faking a flu one time in the hopes that it might stop them from giving it
  • Sadly, this 'experimental treatment' killed him not long after in January 8, the next year
  • US government and army tried to cover it up for 22 years
  • Eventually post-humorously awarded 700,000 for his troubles


d. Ken Kesey - author of "One flew over the Cuckoo's Nest"

  • It is a fun fact that Kesey actually participated in some of the voluntary MK-Ultra experiments at university, in addition to his recreational use on the side

I apologise that this was not written out quite as nicely as my first post in this series, but I already had these notes in a fairly organised format, and I thought that in some ways it might be nicer to simply read it like this. I find it absolutely crazy that this kind of experimentation went on so recently in the past, and also that the MK-Ultra experiments seem to have been largely ignored whenever psychedelics are brought up in the media.


The re-adoption of psychedelics such as LSD and Psilocybin (component of magic mushrooms) in science is fairly fascinating topic in and of itself - indeed, I think Charles Hoskinson even spoke a little about them in an AMA. I may even eventually try to write an article about some of the research being done into 'pscyhedelic-assisted psychotherapy in the future'; however, I will highlight two key points I hope people take away from this:


  • Research during political unrest, for instance during the cold war, though effective at progressing science, is rarely as beneficent as research performed during times of peace. It is for this reason that all research, regardless of the situation, should now pass stringent ethical standards and be as transparent as is feasible for those participating (obviously double-blind experiments must keep some information hidden).
  • Psychedelics are fascinating, and they have a special place in the 1900s history of America with regard to the 'Hippie' movements. However, they also have a much darker past, one which reminds us of the risks and dangers of their abuse; which many of their proponents would rather leave in the oblivion of forgetfulness and shame.


Hope you've learnt something and enjoyed yourself along the way! These notes were created largely from a lecture in the Great Courses series, as well as a few online articles. If anyone identifies any errors, please let me know!


-LogicalLadder

posts.text:
What plagues humanity?

Why are we swinging for the fences in the dark?

What is it that holds us back?

The plague is deception, deception upon perceiving what is.

Worse than any viral threat, it poisons all we work hard for and leaves us wanting.

This deception is in hiding what is so we will forever as a collective remain blind to who we are, why we are here and what is truly possible in life.

We are led to believe it is us, that we are deficient by some sort of lack of effort to accumulate material gains in excess and that only when we over produce this hypothetical national pastime of excessive loss and zero gain can we truly pursue happiness.

This ongoing deception in what truly matters keeps us in the dark. No matter how hard we work, no matter how much we save and no matter how much we learn; there is no escape, no exit, no excuse.

So we keep swinging for the fences, shooting for the moon, because this is all we are allowed to believe, that the odds show if we connect with anything it will all be worth it.

In truth, there are no questions, no seeking, everything has been found at what is.

We are held back because our gods do not exist, we believe we have conquered nature and so we have been as ignorant as we possibly could be by having forsaken our only true teacher, our nature within, whom eternally whispers in full transparency, I am thee one.

Until then like children, the emperor will scold us with no nose, because no one knows it does not exist and has no knows. Continuing the deception through this false belief, that it knows what is best for us, when it only takes existence from those who believe and gives nothing in return.

posts.text:
As a professional editor, writer and tutor, I empathise with any student who finds it hard writing a critical essay.

The trick is to make it easier by understanding the psychology behind the actual writing part, and this then makes the process of putting of words on paper (or typing them into a word processor) in a critical manner less arduous.

By far the most common cause of writers block in any field or genre of writing is not knowing why you are committing words to paper in the first place, and hence (as you already suspect with a painful twinge as you write) these words have no hope of ever forming a cohesive whole let alone a critical whole. This is the equivalent of climbing into a car with no starting point and no destination and then wondering why the journey is unfocussed, shambolic, and seemingly without end.

It is an extremely stressful way to go about achieving effective outcomes in any endeavour: essay writing is no exception.

In this post, I will eschew all the largely generic, aphoristic stuff they teach you in the writing books (make sure you have a beginning middle and end, which is too condescending to be really useful), and tackle the thinking you need to adopt to make the process easier.

I assure you, once you get the psychology behind the process right, and then the process of writing critically itself becomes much easier.

Step 1. Know your Audience

Any writer in any field or genre who wishes to succeed with his or her writing must know his or her audience and write for them in content, structure and style if the writer is to effectively engage the reader. This is equally as important in essay writing as it is in any form of writing that is intended to be read by others though it is an aspect of essay writing that is rarely addressed.


And this, Im afraid, means as much as the radical section of the student population out there might despise the notion you must actually write stuff your tutor wants to read.


And what they want to read is critical. No more, no less.


So make sure you pay attention in lectures, gather materials that argue both for and against your tutors position, and then you can confidently approach the research phase of your essay with knowledge of what will and wont work to engage your audience (your tutor) and win your argument.

Step 2. Make your Argument

The core of a good critical essay is to formulate the question (or statement) into an argument structure. This is important for three reasons: 1) it is easier to write an essay if you know the perspective from which you are writing; 2) it is easier to structure and hence organise your materials; and 3) you can ensure the side you fall down on as regards your argument is consistent with current best practices, theories and research in whatever course or subject you are doing. (See Step 1. Know Your Audience.)

Even if you wish to take a radical stance, and decide not to come down on the currently populist side of the argument (which may work in some cases, depending on your tutor and his or her penchant for radicalism and, indeed, his or her personal perspective on the subject), you still need to ensure you know what the counter-argument is by structuring information in an ordered fashion. (See Step 3. Structuring Information.)

As ever, the rule here with any academic or intellectual endeavour is that you are indeed allowed to think out of the box but you first need to know where the box is!

Step 3. Structuring Information

As noted in Step 2, you are indeed allowed to think out of the box as regards your essay writing, but you first need to know where the box is.

Finding the box is actually simple if you follow this process: take a sheet of paper and draw two columns. Mark column 1 as For and column 2 as Against. Fill these two columns with quotes/references from authors, papers and journals that consistently back up/refute your argument (or counter-argument).

Then, as you write you merely need to phrase your essay as follows, bearing in mind which side you come down on:

[INSERT: Author/Researcher from column 1] notes that [INSERT: a concept, point or quote that backs up your argument] whereas [INSERT: Author/Researcher from column 2] suggests the opposite. However, when all the evidence is taken into objective account [INSERT: Author/Researcher from column 2] fails to fully rationalise this position with the required academic rigour, whereas [INSERT: Author/Researcher from column 1]s rationale for his/her position is well documented in [INSERT: articles, sources and researchers that you were given in your course notes you are required to reference].

Done! The cyclical nature of the above argument structure can be used for an entire essay or dissertation. Moreover, the style and tone allows you in conjunction with this structure to come down on one side of your argument whilst still maintaining academic objectivity.

The bottom line is if you get into the habit of using the above structure it is far easier to keep your own argument straight in your mind, reducing stress and allowing you to produce work confident in the knowledge it is relevant and focused.

Step 4. Winning the Argument.

Winning your own argument (which in essence is what an essay is all about) should be fairly straightforward, so it is surprising how many essays (the majority) I see where the writer loses his or her own argument in the first sentence.

To understand how to win an argument, it is worth understanding good debating structure: I spent many years as both a debater and moderator and I can narrow down for you how you can win any argument even an argument that is factually wrong.

Ultimately, debates are won by taking at the outset the position of the broadest possible argument; debates are lost by getting bogged down in those pesky things called details.

Thus, we need to codify the broadest possible argument imaginable and then any argument can be won in a written essay by employing it.

Philosophically, then, in my experience the widest possible, reductive argument in our human experience is:

There is no such thing as an objective truth; if this is accepted as true, then there is no subjective fact that can refute this position.

QED. Argument won in the first line of the essay!

And if that sounds just a little too hypothetical for, say, your upcoming social work essay titled, Describe how to best access local support for service users with dementia, it actually isnt. The more simple and practical the easy question, the easier it is to set it up as a non-refutable argument due to the level of detail given to you. (The question actually tells you how to win the argument.)

Thus, the opening line for the above essay topic could not be refuted if written as follows:

Local support for service users with dementia are best accessed once an assessment of the service user has been undertaken, due to the fact there is a wide array of services available and must be tailored to the specific needs of individual clients in a holistic manner.

That sentence has no purpose other than to clearly state to your reader that there is no objective truth in the matter of best access as there are too many variables and contributing factors. Thus, having stated this clearly, there is no single subjective fact or facts (which will comprise the majority of the rest of your essay) that could thereafter refute that statement. Argument won.
posts.title: Four Steps to Writing Critically and Compellingly

posts.text:
It is always worth looking at how great writers structure and articulate their work in order to learn from their successes and sometimes failures.

D.H.Lawrence is one of the greatest writers of English prose, however his novel Kangaroo is viewed by many as a flawed work.

In the later stages of the novel, the protagonist, Richard Lovat Somers (who is D.H. Lawrence in all but biographical name, and like him a a smallish man, pale-faced, with a dark beard) grows in his own estimation, until he is laying down the law on how England should have won the war sooner if only Englishmen had been manly enough:

"If men had kept their souls firm and integral through the years, the war would never have come on. If, in the beginning, there had been enough strong, proud souls in England to concentrate the English feeling into stern, fierce, honourable fighting,, the war would never have gone as it went. But England slopped and wobbled, and the tide of horror accumulated."

What does this mean? That the B.E.F. should not have retreated at Mons? It has much more to do with macho fantasy than with any military reality.

The fantasy Australians of the novel all want Lawrence/Somers on their side because he is so rugged and individualistic, but eventually he decides that he is actually too rugged and individualistic to join any side whatsoever. Kangaroo is shot, and Somers/Lawrence goes away, having, it is implied, got a lot of nasty stuff out of his system. It probably worked better as therapy than as a novel.

Considered as a novel, his Kangaroo is a broken-backed unsatisfactory work, but as a human document it is engrossing, revealing the pain of a man whom the war has excluded from the community to which he feels he rightfully belongs.

The first half of the book is a none-too-convincing State-of-Australia novel, by someone who had seen very little of the country. He arrived there by boat on May 4th,1922, spent a few weeks in Western Australia, where he met literary types that he didnt care for much, then headed East to Sydney, where he seems to have had minimal contact with Australians, speaking with very few of them, but immediately started writing a novel that is set in Sydney and full of conversations. He wrote furiously for two months, and finished before he left Australia on August 11th, having maintained an astonishing rate of over 3000 words a day.

These imaginary conversations tend towards the wish-fulfilling. Somers meets up with manly Australian types who grip his biceps and tell him things like:

Youre a stranger here. Youre from the old country. Youre different from us. But youre a man we want, and youre a man weve got to keep. I know it.

and

Mr. Somers. You are the man I have been waiting for

Typically, the men that Somers talks with and impresses are ex-soldiers; they have intense political projects, in which they want to involve Somers, because they sense his energy and manliness. Mostly the conversation is conducted in big generalities, about the need for change and revolution; Somers rarely comes to specifics of policy, and when he does it is saloon-bar philosophy on the level of:

"if I could Id just leave the Irish to themselves, as they want, and let them wipe each other out or kiss and make friends as they please.

More often, though, the talk is about Democracy. In Australia, Somers for the first time felt himself immersed in real democracyin spite of all disparity in wealth. On the whole he approves of this, though there is a feeling that he came to Australia looking for wilderness, and instead found suburbia miles and miles of bungalows with names like Wyewurk and Torestin. Somers is of the common people, we are often reminded, but he cant help a snobbery about such things.

Finally, though, he does not really believe in Democracy, because of the disparity between humans. He believes in leadership and the exercise of power, and this is why he is attracted to the fascist-style leader, Kangaroo, who says things like:

I want to keep ORDER. I want to remove physical misery as far as possible. That I am sure of. And that you can only do by exerting strong, just POWER from above. There I agree with you.

You dont believe in education?

Not much. That is to say, in ninety per cent of the people it is useless. But I do want those ninety per cent none the less to have full, substantial lives: as even slaves had under certain masters and as our people hardly have at all.

Most of us are only fit to be slaves, apparently, and the book is in two minds about whether we have souls. While Lawrence often reiterates that every human has a precious unique soul it seems that your man in the street somehow has not hes only got a minute share of the collective soul. Soul of his own he has none: and never will have. Just a share in the collective soul, no more. The contradiction generally boils down to people of whom Lawrence/ Somers approves having souls, and the rest of us not.

As a novel the book is lacking, but as a document from a psychological case study, it is absorbing.
posts.title: D.H.Lawrence: Learning From the Masters

posts.text:
Saul Bellow, the famous Canadian-American author published 14 novels and novellas, winning the Nobel for writing in 1976. He beautifully described the intimacy between the writer and the reader:

"When you open a novel and I mean of course the real thing you enter into a state of intimacy with its writer. You hear a voice or, more significantly, an individual tone under the words It is more musical than verbal, and it is the characteristic signature of a person, of a soul. Such a writer has power over distraction and fragmentation, and out of distressing unrest, even from the edge of chaos, he [or she] can bring unity and carry us into a state of intransitive attention. People hunger for this."

Maria Popova, she of the excellent blog Brain Pickings, describes why Bellows advice is relevant for todays writer:

"How poignant to consider Bellows remarks in our age where people seem to hunger for cat videos and where the writers voice is being increasingly muffled by the content-producers agenda and yet, and yet, when we do encounter those ever-rarer essences today, those oases of absolute intimacy with another mind, how transcendent our emotional completeness then."

As Bellows and Popova make clear, write to connect with your readers. Show them what both you and your characters think and feel and experience. Think of it like this: a blockbuster novel needs tension and suspense and the other ingredients of a good story. Yet when you connect with readers and pour your own unique perspective and temperament into your work, you can connect with readers even without an overwrought plot or the worlds greatest writing style.
posts.title: Why it is Important to Write to Connect
