I did get a chance to read a little on the tag's purpose....it says the tag is there to expedite the transaction, and without the tag it's simply going to take longer to reach your wallet.

Can anyone confirmed that?...or can anybody help me with this disaster?....thanks!.
posts.title: Can someone reclaim their xrp if they didn't use a tag for the transfer?

posts.text:
Director Robert Zemeckis and writer Steven Knight seem to have been inspired by nostalgic cries of they dont make movies like they used to anymore from somewhere amidst the older segment of the movie going demographic.

Thank the merciful heavens, then (this imagined demographic might be thinking), that Allied came along!

And thank God that it did if for no other reason to prove why you shouldnt make them like that anymore, that is. (And since this stinker, nobody has, mercifully.)

The irony Zemeckis obviously doesnt appreciate is that they never did make them like that.

The problem with making a homage when seen through the rose-tinted prism of nostalgia is that you fail to make a movie that is, of and for its time. Allied feels and looks like a certain spy thriller genre that Hollywood was enamoured of in the 1940s.

But all the pacing, wit and drama that such a genre implies is strangely because entirely absent.

The stellar cast, Pitt and Cotillard in particular, go through the motions. Pitt in particular looks like he'd rather be almost anywhere else (except a private jet with a free bar surrounded by screaming kids). The central love story is about as convincing as wooden six pence piece with Abraham Lincolns head stamped with a branding iron on one side a detriment to the genre that didnt seem to bother Zemeckis, so intent was he on period detail, crashing planes and sandstorms.

Spectacles he certainly excels at better than picking a story with a narrative that actually delivers any tension.

Ultimately, the film is guilty of the only crime that matters in any entertainment: it fails to entertain. Yawn.

Recommend: For anyone with insomnia or an unquenchable penchant for a parade of handsome OTT nostalgia tropes.
posts.title: Unallied to Story or Plot

posts.text:
Okay, this movie isn't as bad as the trailers they were showing at the time would have had us believe, but it's pretty close: it's the comedic equivalent of drinking battery acid. Caustic. Corrosive. And about as funny as slick banana peels. (Gives you an idea of how really, mesmerizingly bad the trailer is!)

Frankly, two hours of static is a lot funnier than 98% of the 'jokes' in this movie.

And, no, its not because I am a misogynist: that was just director, Paul Feig, and the studios vehement retort to anyone that said this film was a knot of cinematic bile (which is anyone with even the faintest affection for the original... or salvageable comedy).

Lets keep it real: you could have taken any group of middle-of-the-road comedians of any race, creed, gender or ethnicity and it still would have been this disappointment of okay, alright already not exactly the monumental proportions fans and critics were fearing. But it's still pretty stodgy comedic fare.


Sure, Kristen Wiig needs to be told she isnt funny without a much stronger comedic foil (hint, it isnt Melissa McCarthy: how many unfunny films do we need to prove that?). And, sure, the director and cast responsible for the truly appalling Bridesmaids (remember how we were all supposed to agree how funny that improvised disaster was?) was always going to screw this up anyway.

But credit to all involved for a watchable cinematic car wreck that at least doesn't injure those involved too badly: avoid a sequel to this and careers can mostly be saved.

Mostly. The film fails on a critical and irredeemable level: Feig never understood what it was about the source material that audiences loved. At all. In any way shape or form. In fact, judging by this misfire its difficult to believe he ever actually watched them.

The original Ghostbusters movies worked because Murray, Ackroyd (whose official comment on this mess is 'no comment'), et al played it straight in a concept that was admittedly OTT bonkers, but went to great pains to get the supernatural stuff right in terms of current research on the subject.


In other words, they respected the material as a vehicle for their comedic talents. This remake (why oh why make is it a remake?) has decided to go the pop-culture reference route (the power of Patty compels you) and plays the whole thing like a series of sub-par, disjointed SNL sketches, seemingly sending up the original.

Badly.

Recommended: For anyone who wants to take notes on how not to make a comedy or a remake.
posts.title: Ghostbusters Reboot: Don't Answer The Call

posts.text:
Hoh-oh-oh, boy. Where did it all go so, so wrong? As most online movie reviews pointed out at the time, Suicide Squad was one of the most disappointing big budget blockbuster misfires of 2016.

And thats a big shame huge for any self-respecting DC comic book movie fan or exhausted cinema goer. (Anyone all universed out and looking for a movie that is contained in and of itself, and is not merely a feature-length promo for other hopefully better movies should stop reading now.)

The problems with this epic misfire (yes, another one) are legion, with little to be had in the way of entertainment or amusement. (God forbid a DC comic book movie ever actually being fun.)

The story (what there is of it) is predictable tosh, under-utilising both the premise and the potential of the characters but well get to that in a minute.

From the broader perspective of these billion dollar DC comic book movie turkeys, a question needs to be raised: who the hell is (or should that be were as the abominable Justice League seems to have killed the current gloomy incarnation) writing (and approving) the shooting scripts for the DC extended universe films? (Zack Synder, we're looking at you.) Almost to a fault they are shoddily structured, with narrative holes large enough to drive a tank through, and, in the case of Man of Steel and Batman v Superman endings that are actually inferior and I am being quite literal here to mediocre fan fiction.

Of course the answer to that question is probably not as straight forward as critics jibes would imply. Suicide Squad never had a single script as such as it was originally shot from director David Ayers own screenplay, and then someone somewhere in a suit decided it had to be made funnier. Oops.

I touched on this in an earlier Trailer Review: basically, the trailer was cobbled together from the completed footage available at the time, and the fan response to the humour was overwhelming. Then it leaked out that the only jokes the film actually contained were all in the trailer, triggering tens of millions of dollars in reshoots to shoehorn in what, as it now turns out, are a few more, fairly lame attempts at humour that probably made David Ayers wife laugh but nobody else.

And this seems to be indicative of the product we got. Ayers oeuvre does not exactly suggest a writer/director with a gift for combining the grittily realistic with comic book humour or anything resembling humour for that matter. He was drafted in off the back of his tough street dramas (End of Watch, Training Day) to maintain what was at the time DCs Nolan-esque notion of a dark and humourless DC universe (which we are certainly getting).

This dour take on the DC universe, as it turns out, is not surprise, surprise what fans wanted. (Gee, no kidding: they had been voicing that polemic since Man of Steel.) So Ayers was left in the unhappy predicament of having to turn Suicide Squad from Fury (not exactly a Chuckle Brothers reunion special) into Deadpool in a few short months.

And that went about as well as expected: the evidence is on the screen.

And the story? Well, that term needs to be used loosely in the case of a film that requires setting up the back stories and character arcs of the six lead characters characters who you know as much about going into the cinema as you could glean from the garish billboards plastered across every city in the developed world.

Which isn't much.

So how does a writer/director of Ayers reputed calibre and standing deal with this admittedly difficult challenge? Why, of course! He throws away the first rule of storytelling, show dont tell, and introduces the characters by way of, er, (Deadpool-lite) expository cartoon bubbles/comic book panels. Yawn.

Yep, thats the movie youre getting people. It doesnt care how it gets from point A to point B, but it will get there and good film making and storytelling be damned.

To move things forward in this review (a phrase we are betting was never once uttered in a Warner Brothers script meeting for the film) we are not going to list each and every character here: look them up on their Wikipedia pages if you feel a more intimate knowledge of their character traits will aid your understanding (it wont) of what are admittedly fairly boring characters with boring powers that barely rate as super. Captain Boomerang (Jai Courtney in a surprisingly engaging performance and, yes the actor is actually Australian), for example here it comes er, throws boomerangs. Thats about as super as Hawkeye in The Avengers, who, er, shoots arrows. Sigh.

Suffice to say, cramming that much exposition and back story in so early on is confusing.

And, if you arent already confused enough thirty minutes in, two more squad members are introduced: Katana (Karen Fukuhara), a samurai warrior whose sword steals souls, and Slipknot (Adam Beach), the so-called man who can climb anything. So, er, Spiderman without any of the cool powers then?

Still, it has to be said, the movie does bring with it a stellar cast, and, as you might have guessed, it is Will Smiths Deadshot and Margot Robbies Harley Quinn who steal the show (regrettably, one not worth stealing). They are the only two characters to be given anything to work with in the way of character and comedic lines, and they do, admittedly, in places the odd scene and line, dont get too excited elevate the uncannily pedestrian material to a level it doesnt deserve.

As for the plot, its pretty much an insane bunch of nonsense that if (unlike Ayer) you're bothered to think it through actually undermines the premise of the film. The villain of the piece is (spoilers ... actually, who cares) a squad member! No, way! Way! Knock me over with a titanium-leafed lead feather!

Enchantress is a possessed archaeologist who defects to the dark(er) side when the government agent responsible for setting up the Suicide Squad sends her in to stop an evil civil calamity unleashed by her demonic brother. Accompanying her is the finest soldier this country ever produced Rick Flag (Joel Kinnaman, after Tom Hardy was forced to drop out due to scheduling conflicts with The Revenant; dodged a bullet there, Tom), a square-jawed Captain America (oh, dont we wish), who is also her love interest.

And, again, sigh. Youd think the film would end right there (if only that were the case) with the Suicide Squad being deemed a pretty bad idea by the military brass overseeing its assemblage; even Flag admits sending in Enchantress was a bad idea. No, really? Duh.

But, nope, they are sent in any way to stop the evil villains from carrying out their plot, the mechanics of which entirely comprise building a machine to destroy all of them (humanity, that is). Er, yep. Thats it. No explanation. No motivation. Nobody cares. (And Ayers wonders why no one went to see this turkey?)

And, yes, it is as about exciting as it sounds.

From there it is one endlessly boring fight scene after another, all shot in darkness at night in a nameless city: characters we dont care about fighting villains were never really introduced to in a generic city (called Midway City) for stakes we never really understand.

For all the exposition in this mess of a movie, Ayers could have at least pointed us in the direction of where he thought his plot was headed.

As for Jared Leto as The Joker how can we put this politely? Lets just say he, ahem, complements the tone and style of the film perfectly: he, like the movie, is wildly vapid and disappointing. For all his boasting about the method acting approach (based on, er, what exactly?) he reputedly took to get into the role, he pretty much just delivers the banal eccentricities of an annoying high school prankster, with no depth or wit.

Leto was clearly going the Heath Ledger route; however, what we end up with here is, at best, a Ledger-lite performance that doesnt even ape the best parts of Ledgers mesmerising portrayal.

It seems that Oscar nomination for Dallas Buyers Club went to Leto's head.

Lets hope Justice League can drag DC out of this pitiful morass of literally unwatchable superhero movies.

Recommended: For rabid, craze-blinded DC fans everywhere.
posts.title: Suicide Squad: Its Not Good To Be This Bad

posts.text:
The misdirection the NYSM2 script would like us to believe is a clever plot device is on par with the improbable onscreen magic tricks the characters conjure up in this insipid attempt to top the original.

Director Louis Leterrier, who helmed the original, at least understood that fun and flash would suffice in an absence of a cogent or remotely plausible plot. Director Jon M. Chu, however, decided that the fun and flash could go and hed substitute a tepid script instead and see how that played. Not well.


The problem is the plot is so arch, convoluted and curiously unengaging that it is hard to relate to the characters.


Woody Harrelsons dual turn as Merrits evil twin brother, sporting fake buckteeth and a weird perma poodle wig, is as at odds with the tone of the piece as Daniel Radcliffes bad guy.


Radcliffe is clearly still on his 'don't call me Harry' bad acting tour de force, and lagging in the memorable parts stakes. His character gets an innovative intro, suggesting were in for a treat of a character, then proceeds to degenerate into a stock villain straight out of central casting.

Sigh. Four Horsemen? It sure feels like the apocalypse.

Call Penn & Teller. And a decent director.


Recommended: For diehard fans of the original only.
posts.title: Now You See Me 2 Lacks, Er, Magic

posts.text:
No one at the time could believe it either. Nor were we aware that the trailer was what we can now see with the benefit of hindsight a bitter sweet portent of the humourless schlock to follow.

Exaggerating? Whos exaggerating? To list DC comic book movies in order of hilarity would require leaving about the top six places with the disclaimer coming soon to a theatre near you maybe.


Out of all DC comic movies, Christopher Nolans The Dark Knight Trilogy is the series most directly responsible for ushering in the whole dark and brooding summer blockbuster trend that is currently blighting mainstream cinema.


Because that style and pace worked so well (for The Dark Knight, anyway) breaking all sorts of box office records on their way to becoming commercial and critical successes (Christian Bale's curiously underwhelming performance aside) studio execs with dollar signs in their eyes, clamored, 'hell then, give the public more of that'.


Sigh.


And so we were burdened with the Man of Steel semi-misfire and the dour BvS disaster a film that no one liked, and was about as much fun as watching a small animal slowly and painfully die in peat bog.


The new Justice League trailer, released along with the Wonder Woman trailer (which was also showing signs of developing a sense of humour, along with the Suicide Squad trailer) at the 2016 San Diego Comic-Concruelly hinted at bucking the humdrum and humourless trend.

The trailer is full of pithy one liners that serve the multiple functions of good dialogue by a) setting the tone, b) revealing subtle character traits, c) providing counterpoint to the darker, more dramatic moments, and d) providing an interesting dynamic between the central characters.

And that's in a three minute trailer. Tight writing indeed.


Sure, Zack Snyder is known for delivering great trailers his movies seem either unwilling or unable to live up to, but this time there were (in the end unfounded rumours) that he might just deliver the goods.


Alas, what a cinematic tonic that would have be: whereas The Avengers even in 2015 continued to inch ever closer to pantomime humour and cartoonish action, the latest Justice League trailer suggested DC might finally have managed to mine their dark and melancholic tone and premise for the type of funny-because-its-poignant-and-true humour that exists at the core of genuine drama.


Now thatwould have beeninteresting.


But we saw how that monumental mess turned out.
posts.title: Fun Fact: Justice League Trailer Actually Delivered The Laughs (No, Seriously)

posts.text:
Online movie reviews doing the rounds at the time for this creatively bankrupt franchise were not kind, with the movie review aggregate site, Rotten Tomatoes still sitting on an 11% fresh rating. Ouch.

This entry must surely represent the nail in the coffin of what has become little more than a gravy train for the increasingly ingratiating vocal talent on display.

It is certainly ironic and no coincidence that the funniest character, Scrat, has no lines of dialogue at all.


That is a very telling commentary on a franchise that has become stale, the writing lazy, and the stories (what there is of them) boring, uninspiringly paced and interminably lo-o-o-o-ong (even at 100 minutes).


To be fair, the bulk of the narratives in the preceding entries were as plodding as the lead characters, Manny (the ever-unfunny Ray Roman on autopilot) ... and family and friends et al are uninspiring.


But Romano is in good company here with his trite comedic shtick to be fair, its not entirely his fault: he has to work with the material he is given (and nine seasons of Everybody Loves Raymond proved hes not very good at doing that).


And thats always been the problem with the Ice Age films: the bland, dim-witted characters pretty much rely on the goodwill of the audience to sustain their onscreen antics, which were never exactly enthralling anyway.


And five films in, that goodwill has all but dried up.


Ultimately the whole Manny/Sid/Diego dynamic ends up being about as interesting as a stand-up comedy bill featuring Romano, John Leguizamo and Denis Leary.


And, God, spare us that!


Recommended:For anyone who thinks Scrat deserves his own silent movie.
posts.title: Ice Age: Collision Course With Mediocrity

posts.text:
Roland Emmerich, like tofu, metrosexual fashion and post-modern art, is a distinctly acquired taste.

A disaster porn aficionado, the German directors epics are, invariably (much like post-modern art) rendered on a very broad canvas indeed broad and violent. If youre haunted by images of helpless souls running and screaming as their green screen world disintegrates around them for reasons of mendacious weather conditions or the hand of an alien-slash-B-movie-monster, chances are youve seen an Emmerich film or two.

Its been 20 years since Independence Day slayed all comers at the box office; a titan among titans in the heady years of 90s blockbuster disaster pics. Its success, like many of its contemporaries, including Deep Impact, Armageddon, Mars Attacks!, Dantes Peak, Twister and Volcano, did not automatically have money hungry execs screaming 'sequel!' as they do today.
Hence why we had to wait it out for over two decades for a film that, admittedly if this is to be a brutally honest movie review no one was particularly asking for.

The film is as strange a beast as any scaly hybrid Chimera in an Emmerich film; but no stranger than any warmed over main dish, defrosted and shoved down the throats of a guileless public two decades beyond its expiry date. A tainted aftertaste, if a guilty pleasure.
Trick is, to enjoy it for what it is, not for what it is not.

In Independence Day: Resurgence, familiar scenes, slightly tweaked, abound: another massive alien ship approaches an intact White House. This time the craft doesnt destroy it: instead, the ship crawls up and stops just inches away, tipping over a flag a-hoist the building, so close does it park its Darth Vader-lite fender.

And this scene pretty much sets the tone of the film. We get it already: post 9/11, no gratuitous mayhem, no wholesale exploding of public buildings and landmarks. Hollywoods risk-averse studio system, it seems, is more determined than ever to tone down the violence in certain PC quarters.

Bill Pullmans character, Thomas J. Whitmore, the former President he of the gung-ho we will not go quietly into the night speech in the original, is now older, confused, and, it seems, sporting a psychic connection to the extra-terrestrials. (Yep, you read that right.)

To cut a (very) long story short, the set up has it that humanity since the first attack has banded together and exploited the alien technology left behind. The headquarters of the new global Earth Space Defence agency is, naturally, situated in the U.S., where the first female President (Sela Ward) has a policy of shoot first and ask questions later.

From there, so far, so familiar. Jeff Goldblum is back as scientist David Levinson, dispensing mildly erudite, how-to-whoop-ETs-ass consultancy. As with the original, a Top Gun-esque collection of space pilots, this time graced by the likes of Liam Hemsworth (who to thios day still hasnt figured out how to be a bonafide movie star yet) and Jessie Usher, are deployed to supply the requisite POV shots from inside jerky cockpits.

Star Treks, Datas (yes, he was in the original) kooky Area 51 chief, Dr Brakish Okun (Brent Spiner), wakes up from a long coma to befriend an alien sphere that looks like a disused prop from the 1951 B-movie classic The Day The Earth Stood Still. The characters vex over hieroglyphic-like drawings of what appears to be something youd see on a Game Boy era Game Over screen.

And the usual hijinks ensue, with the real battle being between the writers who, it seems, never quite won the war as to who the protagonist should be. But, hey, that didnt stop the original becoming a box office juggernaut.

Worse, for reasons that only a mellowing Emmerich could possibly explain, he decided at some point that what his popcorn film needed was to take a sharp, dark detour down the Christopher Nolan route (have we learned nothing from Batman v Superman?), and the film has a generally heavier feel to it.

Ultimately, IDR, at least when it drops the self-aware shtick and sticks to po-faced camp, is as fun a ride as youd expect. It cant hold a candle to the original but theres enough combat shenanigans between generic aliens and lesser, Tom Cruise-light mortals, to more or less turn the fun-o-meter up to an 7 out of 10, if you like that sort of thing. (To be fair, as online movie reviews go, this review can't hold a candle to some of the vitriol poured upon upon IDR, which currently scores a lowly 24% at Rotten Tomatoes.)

Recommended: For Jeff Goldblum fans after all, no one else in the picture stood a chance, including the aliens, of really putting bums on seats.
posts.title: Independence Day: Resurgent And Reheated

posts.text:
The new Wonder Woman trailer was a surprise release at the 2016 San Diego Comic-Con, dividing fans and online movie reviewers alike.

Some online movie reviewers at the time were bemoaning the inclusion of too much action in the trailer, and surmised, therefore, that the movie (which was, to everybodys surprise, wrapped and in post production) must either be a) non-stop action sacrificing character to the requirements of a big budget, blockbuster movie or b) devoid of enough action, and the trailer has hence given away too much.

Isnt that always the problem with trailers, though?

Ever since original Wonder Woman helmer, Michelle McClaren, was ousted as director over creative differences, the chances of too much action diminished significantly, with the studio reportedly wanting a character piece, and not McClarens vision of an epic origins story in the vein of Braveheart.

A character piece? Its DC not Merchant Ivory. There were high hopes theyd get that balance right (and they kinda did, more or less).

More worrying was Gal Gadots (Fast and the Furious) seeming lack of screen presence and believability in the role (she's easy on the eye, but her acting range seems stuck on 'smouldering'): and now shes tasked with shouldering her own movie.

To be honest, to this day the jurys out on that one.

The upside? At least the tone from what the trailer was showing audiences at the time might might have offered some hope of a DC superhero flick that wasnt as irredeemably bleak and depressing as Man of Steel and Batman V Superman.

And that panned out to be the case, pretty much.

At the time, DC couldnt seem to shake off a severe, chronic case of Nolan-itis. Director Patty Jenkins (Monster) at least managed to lighten things up a little, and, though too little too late, the film we got was a passable slice of what might have been.
posts.title: Wonder Woman Comic-Con Trailer Fails To 'Wow'

posts.text:
The real two-part question most online movie reviewers were asking back when this yawn-fest was released was a) who funded this piece of revisionist history, and b) how (and why oh why) did it merit a theatrical release?

Well keep this one short. Writer/director, Dinesh D'Souzas right wing propaganda piece is a slice of curiously stale madness.

Hillarys America is not necessarily misguided in what it has to say about its subject; it could, however, benefit from toning down the overall ostentatious way it goes about saying it.

In the final analysis, this documentary is really just a grab bag of conspiratorial talking points reshuffled into an order that helps DSouza make his wildly paranoid points and history be damned!

Recommended: For any right wing nuts who think Breitbart isnt conservative enough.
posts.title: Hillary's America: Right Wing Revisionism

posts.text:
Online movie reviews for the fourth instalment of the Bourne franchise all noted the rot that had begun to set in: the films still boast a great concept and premise but it's a concept that is running out of steam.

All the elements are present and correct: documentary style photography that lends the action in particular an air of frenetic immediacy. Check. Rogue CIA factions out to protect their interests at all costs. Check. Potential love interests for Bourne that director Paul Greengrass turns into cannon fodder with the glee of someone in the know subverting a Bond-esque spy trope. Check.

Etcetera.

The problem is the story: there isnt one.

Well, not really and certainly nothing groundbreaking, or anything anyone was clamouring for after a decade's hiatus.

It is a film that is essentially aping its own former greatness.

The Bourne Trilogy worked so well because it had a nifty character and narrative arc that easily fleshed out three taut, suspenseful films. The premise was eloquent in its simplicity: Bourne had amnesia, and gradually over three films he remembered more and more until armed with full knowledge he could confront those who betrayed him.

No more amnesia, no more Bourne films. End of story (you might have thought).

But, oh no. With Jason Bourne (and future instalments, God forbid) they have decided to go a route that is really testing audiences patience: Greengrass is now basically using the amnesia conceit as an all-encompassing technique to manufacture suspense where none existed or should exist.

In Jason Bourne, the central character now has additional flashbacks (that we had not been privy to in the other three movies), and he then has to come to terms with these as surprise, surprise they somehow relate to his original predicament. (I get it but does Greengrass its a fine line between inspired and contrived.) Huh. Convenient.

If convoluted. Jason Bourne has, essentially, revealed the trick card up the directors sleeve.

If this is how youre going to spin out your premise then where will it end: why not have Bourne remembering flashbacks about an alien abduction that the CIA wanted to cover up in order that they could trade human specimens for alien technology, and it is this technology Bourne was really tricked into protecting in Identity, and not American lives, who are now alien chum, and Bourne must now save them with a stolen alien super weapon the CIA had been hiding in Area 51 all along?

See, it's not hard to do, but it's cheating the audience with the very creative conceit that attracted cinema goers in the first place.

Still, admittedly, that premise would have been a better movie than Jason Bourne.

Recommended: For anyone who likes whiplash via choppy camera work this film was written by a film editor.
posts.title: Jason Bourne: About As Inspired As The Title

posts.text:
In the mid 1990s the economic and social makeup of Amsterdam began to transform.The transition to a primarily service oriented city, as opposed to an industrial hub, continued while in the process many factories closed.This inevitable fate also claimed the historic shipyard on the banks of the River IJ inAmsterdamNoord, which is located in the NDSM wharf.The neighbourhood was for a long time considered unsafe, and so the giant building stood abandoned and unoccupied with few daring to venture into the area.

However, in time a small band of intrepid artists relocated to the island and, finding the abandoned shipyard to be a Mecca if open space and filtered light (not to mention easy on their impecunious pockets), decided to set up a collection of informal art studios.As time went on, and word got out, increasingly more artistically inclined squatters arrived and the community thrived and grew, eventually expanding beyond the abandoned shipyard and into the surrounding neighbourhood.

With only a tolerance and respect for their artistic history the Dutch could manage, as the areas population increased and it became safer the city of Amsterdam bought the enormous shipyard and formalised the arrangements.The artists were not kicked out (as they would have been in any other large, expensive metro area in any other European city) but were instead offered formal studio rentals. This encouraged developers to move in and consolidate the areas gentrification with housing, all while leaving the NDSMs pocket of creativity intact.

Having said that, todays NDSM though still artsy is developing at a rapid pace.Today, theNDSM Wharfhas blossomed into a wildly popular cultural hotspot, with the vibrant artist community complemented by an ever-expanding variety of bars and restaurants. This had meant, as it usually does in such cases, hipsters have continued to follow the artists and property prices on the island are heading in a corresponding upward trajectory.

Regardless, the old shipyard building, now thriving and welcoming in all its monumental bulk, is still here.The space comprises over 300 studios that visitors can tour.However, there is a great deal more artwork to be discovered on the island than what is contained in the old shipyard alone.Make sure you mix and mingle with the local artists who are more than happy to show you treasure troves of undiscovered artwork on the island, located in the area of the shipyard.

More than likely, unexpected adventures will take you far off course, but it is precisely that spirit of adventure that drew artists to the island in the first place.

Know Before You Go

NDSM is located outside the city centre in the northern part of Amsterdam, but it is easy convenient to reachby Ferry 906m which arrives at the harbour of NDSM in around 14 minutes. It can also be reached with Houthaven Ferry (903) fromAmsterdam West.

Travel Tip: Rent a bike at one of thebicycle rentalsin the old city of Amsterdam, take the ferry and visit and discoverAmsterdam Noordand the post-industrial monuments of the NDSM terrain by bike.
posts.title: Van Gogh Would Approve  Amsterdam, The Netherlands

posts.text:
Walthamstow, a fringe district on Londons northeast borders, was long considered an unremarkable collection of drab gray flats and urine yellow tower blocks. However, times have changed and in line with many areas of London being gentrified, Walthamstow, like Bethnal Green and Shoreditch before it, has seen an influx of curious creatives and millennial hipsters into the area. These two facets of changing Walthamstow collide in the purple explosion of colour and light that is Gods Own Junkyard.

Gods Own Junkyard is located in an old industrial estate, and is curated by Marcus Bracey, who calls defines his creative niche as neon artist. It is true, there is neon to spare: stand back and admire a kaleidoscopic jumble of handmade neon signs that resemble a cut price Las Vegas strip only minus the girls and gaudy facades of hotels and casinos. As for the purpose of Gods Own Junkyard, the place serves as Bracey explains many functions: part free art gallery, part dealer and signage recycler for shops and businesses, part prop shop for photo and film locations sought by psychedelically inclined film makers and photographers, part restaurant and caf space, and all lucrative customer for whichever local utility company is lucky enough to supply their electricity.

The collection of elaborately lit paraphernalia includes thousands of props, signs and gaudily dressed mannequin figures displayed within this large, open warehouse space. Cheerfully winking emblems destined for avant guard restaurants and hotels gleam from all the free wall space. Stacked high from the raw warehouse floor and dangling like lurid mobiles from the ceiling are totems paying tribute to every form of disreputable entertainment: karaoke, cocktails, rock n roll, disco, pinball, casinos. Adding to the decadence, garish displays, inspired by and in some cases designed for the Old Soho vice dens (themselves retro throwbacks to more carnal pleasures in more decadent times) neon-accented religious images stand, arms gesturing in unholy tableau.

Speaking to The Independent newspaper to describe the experience he wants to give visitors, Bracey said: You stand back and look at it, and thats what really gives you the kick.

Know Before You Go

Open to the public only on weekends (exact hours listed on their website), but with places to eat and nearby attractions within easy reach you can make a day or even an evening of it. There is an onsite cafe serving coffee, snacks and alcoholic beverages. There is also a scattering of establishments serving craft beers, cocktails and food. The industrial estate is located around a 15-minute walk from Walthamstow Central Station on the London Victoria and Overground lines. Detailed walking directions can be found here: http://www.godsownjunkyard.co.uk/directions.html
posts.title: This Trip is Psychedelic, Man  London, UK

posts.text:
Although it is full of stunning beaches and views of volcanic mountains, non-essential travel to this tropical wonder is not recommended.

The Sulu Archipelago and the island of Mindanao are specifically noted as dangerous due to terrorist and insurgent activities. Foreign travelers, Filipino-Americans in particular, have been targeted by gangs as victims of kidnappings in the past, and bombings and armed confrontation are also a threat.

Opportunistic crimes, like cons, pickpocketing, and credit card fraud, are also commonly expereienced by tourists.

Before you go

Think twice.
posts.title: If Bombings and Kidnappings are Your Thing - The Philippines

posts.text:
You read that right. For all you Potter fans out there, Leadenhall Market, an ornate Central London Victorian marketplace doubled as the setting for Diagon Alley as well as the Leaky Cauldron in the Harry Potter films.

Long before its starring role in the Harry Potter films, the immaculately cobbled floors and ornate 19TH-Century roof, nestled in the historic heart of Londons financial district, already made it a popular destination of locals and tourists alike, and a magical place to spend some time shopping, eating and drinking.

Ranking as one of the oldest covered Victorian markets in London, Leadenhall market has specialised is the sale of fish and meat as far back as far as the mid 14th century, at which time it was an open air market. That all changed in 1881 when the Victorians, hankering to shop for wares out of the indeterminate London weather, constructed the current painted red and green, which then made the market the popular London attraction still popular today.

The market featured several times in the Harry Potter series. Some of the original exterior shots of Diagon Alley the high-ceilinged and cobblestoned wizarding shopping enclave where Hogwarts students stock up on spell books, wands and other school supplies show the markets unmistakable architecture.

The Potter reminders can be seen elsewhere: wander down the markets Bulls Head Passage and the blue door of a present day opticians (the storefront had been empty at the time of shooting) may look familiar: in Goblet of Fire, it served as the entrance to the Leaky Cauldron. In the films, Diagon Alley is only accessible to witches and wizards through the Leaky Cauldron, which is actually a traditional pub located next to a record store. Muggles beware trying to cross over and usually opt for a pint instead!

Know Before You Go

The interior of the market itself is generally accessible 24/7, and used by locals as a shortcut between surrounding streets. The shop hours, however, vary and sometimes operate limited hours.
posts.title: Harry Potter Shops Here  London, UK

posts.text:
Prestonpans, or Preston, is a small coastal region that lies some 50 miles east of Edinburgh. It currently boasts a vast number of murals painted by members of the local community and guest artists. It also happens to be the site of a historic battle. Here, Charles Edward Stuart suffered a massive defeat in an attempt to regain the monarchy. Dotted around this quaint village are several reminders of this troublesome era. One such example is the Preston Tower.

Dating from the early part of the 17th-century, the township of Preston was granted permission to hold a weekly market and annual fair. As a part of this prestigious distinction, the township was honored with a market cross. This is one of two specifically designed market crosses surviving in Scotland. Its also the only such structure still in its original location.
The Preston Cross is constructed of yellow sandstone, octangular in shape, and consists of two doors. At the ground level of the cross resides a circular room that functioned as the towns jail. Here, convicted criminals would be held for a variety of infractions ranging from public intoxicationto committing slander and not attending church services.

Above this lockup, connected by a narrow stairway, is a raised platform. From here, proclamations were read out to the gathered townspeople. These wouldve included royal announcements, as well as public decrees. In the center of this podium is a column topped with the symbol of Scotland, a unicorn holding a shield with a red lion.

Know Before You Go

Visible and accessible at all hours of the day. Though there is no entry, the nearby Preston Tower is well worth a visit.
posts.title: Returning Market Value - Preston, Scotland

posts.text:
Thousands of skulls, plus another 21,000 skeletons located just below the main vestry, decorate the walls and ceiling of a Polish church called Kaplica Czaszek: The Chapel of Skulls.

Ii 1776, while America was fighting for independence from England, with the American revolutionary war piling up bodies, bodies were also piling up a in the small Polish town of Czermna, (located a kilometer to the north of Kudowa Zdroj), courtesy of a priest and a local grave digger, but under a very different set of circumstances.

The skulls and bones of over 3,000 people reside (if thats the right word) within the modest-looking St. Batholomews Church. This veritable bone tapestry decorates the ceiling and walls, and the bones are arranged in very specific patterns. The majority are arranged in an eerie, Jolly Roger-style, repeating the crossed bones motif across large sections of walls and ceiling. And that is before we consider the 21,000 skeletons stuffed in the church crypt below, less garishly patterned if not entirely forgotten.

It is a strange example of some very macabre history indeed, with unclear motivations. Collected by Czech priest Vaclav Tomasek and J. Langer, the local grave digger, it took them around 18 years, from 1776 to 1794, to collect, polish and arrange as many as 24,000 human skeletons, which still pack the church to this day. While most of the skeletons are stacked in a crypt beneath the church, which is around 20-foot deep, the rest are majestically, if morbidly, displayed in what Tomasek viewed as a sanctuary of silence.

In terms of raw materials, the grotesque pair had plenty to choose from. The Thirty Years War, the Seven Years War, and countless other skirmishes between Hussite, Catholic and Protestants, Poles, Germans and Czech that bordered the Chapels location to say nothing of the cholera epidemics that regularly killed hundreds left plenty of mass graves to choose from. Tomasek is rumoured to have found the mass graves by observing where local dogs spent their time digging for bones.

As the priest and grave digger surfaced and cleaned thousands of skeletons, the unholy pair set aside skulls of special interest to be displayed in the church. The skull display can still be viewed today and includes a wide assortment of exhibits: the skulls of the Czermna mayor and his wife, a Tartar warriors skull skulls riddled with bullet holes, a syphilitic skull resembled Swiss-cheese, and in pride of place on one wall hangs the skull of a giant. Perhaps most poignantly of all, the skulls of the priest and the grave digger themselves now preside proudly over the Chapel of Skulls they created, never flagging in their morbid fervour long enough to consider the place may one day be their final resting place.

Know Before You Go

The custodians of the Chapel currently do not allow photos inside the vestry or crypt. A trapdoor to the crypt below can be opened to view the other 21,000 skeletons stacked just below. The history of the church is explained in a recording, but is currently only available in Czech, Polish and German.
posts.title: Decorating to Die For  Czermna, Poland

posts.text:
The Giant's Causeway, located in Northern Ireland, is a World Heritage Site that features an estimated 37,000 polygon columns so geometrically perfect that local legend has it they were created by a giant.


However, modern geology has put paid to notions of mythic giants wielding the ancient giant equivalent of circular saws and planing tools.


Sixty million years ago a huge volcanic eruption spewed out a mass of molten basalt, which then solidified and contracted as it cooled, creating the cracks that can be seen today.


But don't let that dry scientific explanation destroy the romantic mythos. Explore this amazing natural phenomenon on a grey winter's day and those drawing storm clouds in the distance could just be the stooped backs of giants come to admire their ancient handiwork.


Know Before You Go


To explore the amazing scenery consider taking a day tour from Belfast.
posts.title: Giants Built This Causeway (Maybe)  Northern Ireland

posts.text:
There is an argument that Lake Natron should really come under the heading of "places not to visit" certainly not if you are into swimming in sodium bicarbonate-free water and nature. (Hint: Neither of them are really represented here.)

In this terrifying African lake, animals that die are through a natural process of calcification turned into statues. The presence of enormous amounts of sodium bicarbonate ensures dead animals are effectively mummified. For this reason this lake is also known as the Petrifying Lake for its ability to turn formerly living animals to stone in a similar process to petrifaction.

It gets scarier. Because of the high alkaline collection, the lake appears to be an eerie red in colour, especially during the long, hot Tanzanian summer. People have reported this effect as actually glowing at night under the right atmospheric conditions, giving it the weird appearance of magma boiling in a volcano caldera.

Its not all bad news. Despite these less-than-favourable conditions, Lake Natron is in fact grazing ground for the Lesser Flamingos that inhabit the area, with many of them calcified for eternity on the shoreline. Fancy a swim? Best choose another lake or risk demise by calcification yourself!

Before you go

The best time to visit the lake is June to August. In order to find the lake safely, fly to Tanzania and book a guided tour of Rift Valley of which the lake is a part.
posts.title: This Lake is Scary  Lake Natron, Tanzania
